simplified: Your dreams can give you clues about thoughts you didn’t know you had. Many people have similar dreams, such as flying, falling, losing teeth, or being naked in public. These dreams usually mean something similar for most people. But to understand exactly what a dream means for you, you need to connect it to the events and feelings in your everyday life.
original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.

simplified: One of the most interesting examples of wild animals living in a city is the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow there are about 35,000 wild dogs on the streets. Some dogs were born in the wild, and some are pets that people left behind. Some dogs live alone, while others live in groups. In 2010 scientists studied the dogs and found that they have adapted very well to city life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people, and some dogs seem to understand traffic lights.
original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.

simplified: Wonder is the first novel written by New Yorker RJ Palacio. On her website she says the idea for the book came when she saw a girl with facial deformities (a serious change in the shape of her face) on the street. Wonder has become a bestseller (a very popular book) in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools use it to start talks about bullying, friendship and what it feels like to be different. A movie version is being made, and many people, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.
original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

simplified: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. She knows rats are not usual pets. She has tried many times to tell people that rats are not dirty and can be great pets if they are cared for properly. She understands why some people react badly. Chloe did not like rats at first, but her friend Martin showed her his pet rats. She saw that they are affectionate and smart. Last year, when one of Martin’s rats had babies, Chloe decided she wanted to have two rats of her own.
original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.

simplified: Cape Town can be a risky place for baboons. Some have been hurt or killed in car crashes, and others have been electrocuted (hurt by electricity) when they played with electric wires. Baboons are an endangered species (they are at risk of disappearing). To protect them and lower problems between people and baboons, the city council hired a group of Baboon Monitors. Their job is to drive baboons away from the city or catch them and let them go in the countryside. This plan has worked a little, but it is still hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city because they see it as a place with easy food.
original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.

simplified: I work for a worldwide IT company. Because the main office is in the United States, I do all my work online from home. This means I don’t waste time traveling to work or having small talk with coworkers. I work on a project basis (my work is organized into separate projects), and this flexibility is very important to me because I can easily take time off when my children need me at school performances or when I have a dentist appointment. The downside is that, without set office hours, I often work late into the evening and sometimes skip dinner to finish a task.
original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.

simplified: In the 1990s, graffiti was still common, but street art grew a lot all over the world. Some artists wanted to send political messages, so they made art that made people think about war, unfairness (inequality) and discrimination (treating people badly because of their race, gender, etc.). Other street artists cared more about creating pretty and attractive pictures. In South America, many street artists worked in poor neighbourhoods, adding colour, life and beauty to the dull, grey city walls.
original: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.

simplified: Every day, social media, magazines and shop windows show people many things to buy. British shoppers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever. Online shopping makes it easy to buy without thinking. Big brands sell very cheap clothes, so people treat them like disposable items – they wear them two or three times and then throw them away.
original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.

simplified: Sam squinted (narrowed his eyes) against the bright sun at the dusty trail left by the car that was going up to the Big House (the main house). The horses kicked and swished their tails at flies, not caring that their owner was visiting after ten months. Sam waited. Mr. Carter only came out here when he had to, and Sam liked that. The more Sam stayed out of his boss’s way, the longer he could keep his job. Mr. Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The wet spots on his shirt clumped together like shapes on a map. His skin was already turning red (ruddy) in the June sun. Otherwise, he had the indoor tan of a man who makes money while other people do the work.
original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.

simplified: Many people who live in Berlin, Germany said that shooting pigs is too cruel, and there were strong arguments between hunters and animal lovers. After the protests, the city council (the group that makes decisions for the city) chose a calmer way to deal with the pigs. Instead of shooting them, they built fences and made it against the law to feed the pigs. We will see if this plan works, but it might be difficult because warmer winters mean there are more pigs than before.
original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.

simplified: A big idea for the *Hunger Games* book comes from Suzanne’s love of old Greek myths (stories from ancient Greece). When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was the tale of Theseus and the Minotaur. In that story the city of Athens is controlled by Crete, but the Athenians fight back. As a punishment, Minos, the king of Crete, makes the Athenians send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The young people are put into a labyrinth (a huge maze) where a monster called the Minotaur lives and eats them. One of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne thinks of Katniss Everdeen as a modern‑day Theseus, a hero from the future.
original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.

simplified: Zoos bring people and animals together, so they can teach visitors about protecting nature and inspire them to help animals and their homes. Some zoos give a safe place for animals that were treated badly in circuses or for pets that were left alone. Zoos also do important studies about how animals act and how to treat their diseases.
original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals which have been mistreated in circuses, or pets which have been abandoned. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.

simplified: A new movement is growing that goes against buying a lot – the “buy nothing” movement. It started in Canada in the early 1990s and later spread to the United States. There it became a way to say no to the big spending and buying too much on Black Friday and Cyber Monday, which happen at the end of Thanksgiving. On Buy Nothing Day, people hold protests and even cut up their credit cards (a card used to pay for things). During the rest of the year, Buy Nothing groups help each other trade and fix things they already have.
original: A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day people organise various types of protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organise the exchange and repair of items they already own.

simplified: Is graffiti art or vandalism? It depends on your point of view, but in many countries writing or painting on public or private property is called vandalism (damage or illegal graffiti). Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils say that cleaning graffiti from buildings, buses and trains costs a lot of money.
original: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.

simplified: What do people in the art world think about graffiti and street art? Recently, more people are seeing it as a real kind of art. Big shows of street art have been held in galleries (places that display art) in Paris, London and Los Angeles. In 2008, the American artist Elura Emerald organized a street‑art show in a New York gallery. She defended street artists, saying “artists who paint on the street are just expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be liked and celebrated.”
original: What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been a growing recognition of its value as an art form. There have been major exhibitions of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition at a New York gallery in 2008. She defended street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are merely expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated'.

simplified: Most people have four to six dreams each night after they are ten years old. That means they have about 2,000 dreams every year. By the time they are 80, they may have had around 140,000 dreams in total. Even if we forget 95‑99 % of those dreams, we still remember a few thousand of them during our life. So it is easy to think that, by chance (a coincidence), something that happens in a dream can be followed by a real‑life event that looks similar, especially when the dream is about something that happens often in everyday life.
original: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.

simplified: The Hunger Games is set in the future, after North America has been destroyed. The country is called Panem. It has twelve poor districts that are ruled by the rich Capitol. The Capitol has total power over the country. Each district makes a different product for the Capitol. The story starts in District 12, which provides all the coal. There used to be a thirteenth district, but it rebelled against the Capitol and was destroyed.
original: The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after the destruction of North America. The country is called Panem and is made up of twelve poor districts governed by the wealthy Capitol. The Capitol holds absolute power over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district but they rebelled against the Capitol in the past and were destroyed.

simplified: Often wild animals go into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into neighbourhoods on the edge of the city to eat. They open trash bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even gone inside people’s houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be aggressive (they may act violently) and have attacked many pet animals, so it is easy to understand why many city residents do not welcome them.
original: Often wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas on the edge of the city to feed. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked a lot of pet animals, so understandably, many city residents don't welcome their presence.

simplified: Many bridge accidents happen while the bridge is being built. These accidents are often caused by a mistake made by the engineers, such as a wrong calculation (a miscalculation). The bridge falls down because it cannot hold its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers who are on it at that time.
original: A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.

simplified: George Lucas was one of the first movie makers who used the 17 steps of the “hero’s journey” (a story pattern where an ordinary person is invited to a big adventure). Usually the hero starts the story living a normal life, then something happens that calls them to a life‑changing adventure. At the beginning of *Star Wars*, Luke lives a normal life with his aunt and uncle, fixing robots. When he finds Princess Leia’s message to Obi‑Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2‑D2, that message is the “call to adventure” that starts his journey.
original: George Lucas was one of the early film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero starts the story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.

simplified: Another idea to protect Earth from a dangerous asteroid is to destroy it with a nuclear bomb. It sounds like a movie story – it was the plot of the 1998 film *Armageddon* – but NASA really studied a plan called the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER). In this plan, eight‑ton rockets would be shot at a coming asteroid to try to push it away from Earth. If the asteroid is already too close for this to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to explode the asteroid.
original: Another suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was the subject of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.

simplified: According to Campbell, the hero first says no to the adventure, but then a mentor (a wise guide) appears, helps them, and they decide to “cross the threshold” (go into a new place) and travel into the “special world” where the adventure happens. The next stage is about passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends while the hero gets ready for the biggest challenge. For Luke, the mentor is Obi‑Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO, and the enemy is Darth Vader, all inside the special world of the Death Star.
original: According to Campbell, the hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.

simplified: Some people think items that are not used much are useless, but they can be useful for others. The internet has helped online groups find ways to make money by sharing these items. Websites and social media groups let people buy and sell second‑hand goods, so it is now very easy for people to share directly with each other. This is called the sharing economy.
original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have figured out a way to generate profit from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer sharing activities to take place. And this is known as the sharing economy.

simplified:
In the 1700s and 1800s two main ideas about dreams became popular.  

The first idea said that the pictures we see in dreams stand for things that are hidden from our conscious mind (the part of our mind we are aware of). Freud thought that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause.  

The second idea was the opposite. It said that dreams are just random activity in the brain while it is organising (arranging) memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and turn them into a story.
original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.

simplified:
I work as a freelancer – that means I have my own business and I am not an employee of a company. I like this because I can decide what I do and how I use my time.

At first I tried to work from home, but it was very hard to focus. There were many distractions: I had housework to do, I kept making another cup of tea, and my family members often wanted my attention.

Then I went to a nearby café to work. The internet (Wi‑Fi) was not very good and I ended up drinking too much coffee.

Finally I chose to rent a desk in a co‑working space. A co‑working space is a shared office where several people work together. There were five other freelancers there. I liked getting dressed and going to work in the morning, and I could concentrate better in the office setting.
original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.

simplified: Whether NASA can find the remaining medium‑sized NEOs (near‑Earth objects) depends on getting money to build NEOCam, a 0.5‑metre space telescope that would use infrared light (a type of heat light) to locate asteroids. If it gets the money, it could probably finish its work in ten years. After the asteroids are found, the planetary‑defence team still has to figure out how to protect Earth from the most dangerous asteroids – the PHAs (Potentially Hazardous Asteroids).
original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it did get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.

simplified:
The “buy nothing” trend is now also followed by social‑media influencers – people who often show clothing and make‑up they suggest you buy. Some YouTube stars now tell their viewers to stop buying anything for a long time, even up to a year.

Two friends in Canada tried this for one year. Their goal was to spend money only on food. In the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical items, clothes, or other household things. After that they stopped using services – for example, they did not get haircuts, they did not eat in restaurants, and they did not buy petrol (fuel) for their cars.

After the whole year they had saved $55,000.
original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.

simplified: Religion is very important to Pi. His family follows Hinduism, but Pi is curious about other faiths. He becomes friends with a Christian priest (a church leader) and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi says he is Hindu, Muslim and Christian at the same time (simultaneously). When his family and teachers ask him to choose only one religion, Pi refuses, saying “I just want to love God.” From that moment, his family and teachers let him decide for himself what he believes.
original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.

simplified: Some people think that writing your dreams down can help you start lucid dreaming. Lucid dreaming means you know you are dreaming and you can decide what happens in the dream. So, you could change a scary dream into a safe‑feeling one, or you could guide the story of your dream like a movie director. Then, instead of only trying to understand the meaning of your dreams, you can actually create them. But you might still want some dreams that let your subconscious (the part of your mind that works without you thinking about it) show you what’s on your mind.
original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!

simplified: Many people do not realize they are part of the disposable‑clothing problem when they give their unwanted clothes to charity. Charity shops cannot sell all the clothes they receive. “Fast fashion” – cheap clothes made quickly – becomes out of style as fast as it became popular, and it is often too low‑quality to be recycled (turned into new material). Because of this, people do not want to buy these clothes second‑hand. A lot of the clothes are thrown away, and many of the items that charities cannot sell are sent to other countries, creating more economic (money‑related) and environmental (nature‑related) problems.
original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.

simplified: Not satisfied with just one great trip, many modern adventurers try many challenges. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on every continent, biked across Canada, and ran a long race in the Sahara Desert when the temperature was 45 °C. But her most amazing journey was a ski trip to the South Pole. On the first day she fell into a glacier – a huge, slow‑moving piece of ice – and had to be rescued. Many people would have stopped then, but Meagan kept going. She arrived at the South Pole forty days later, pulling a sled (a small cart) with a tent and all her food through very cold weather and ice storms.
original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.

simplified: Blek le Rat began by painting pictures of rats on walls in his hometown, Paris. Today, he wants people to think about social issues – problems that affect many people in society. He paints images of homeless people in big cities so that residents will notice and consider the problem of homelessness.
original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.

simplified: In some places, local councils (the local government) try to stop artists from painting graffiti anywhere on walls. They do this by giving artists special areas where they are allowed to paint. Taiwan is one of these places; it has “graffiti zones” where artists can freely paint and write on walls. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city council even lets some graffiti artists paint on the city’s subway trains.
original: In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city's subway trains.

simplified: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to work in many different places. Her art can be seen on sidewalks, in empty factories and on old cars. She likes that most street art does not stay forever; it is soon worn away by the weather or cleaned away by the city council (the local government). For her, this shows that life is always changing, with endings and new beginnings.
original: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this reflects how life is full of change with its cycle of endings and new beginnings.

simplified:
Gabriela had previously worked in a company where the hierarchy was strong – people accepted big differences in power and respected the boss’s authority. In that kind of workplace, the boss makes the important decisions and employees rarely question them.  

In her Swedish team, the hierarchy is much flatter. Workers and bosses often discuss problems together and share decisions. Here, the boss acts more like a coach or mentor, encourages people to think for themselves, and expects to be challenged.
original: In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.

simplified: When Gabriela noticed that she and her team came from different cultures, she decided to talk openly with them about how they felt about her leadership. The team was happy that she asked for their opinions. They said they were not used to being told exactly what to do. They liked having space to take their own initiative and be creative. When Gabriela gave them detailed instructions, the team felt she did not trust them to do the job well. They understood that Gabriela felt hurt when they questioned or changed her decisions, and they explained that this was the way they had always worked.
original: When Gabriela became aware of the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. Pleased to be asked for their thoughts, Gabriela's team openly expressed that they were not used to being told what to do. They enjoyed having more room for initiative and creative freedom. When she told her team exactly what she needed them to do, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well. They realised that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes to her decisions, and were able to explain that it was how they'd always worked.

simplified: Os Gêmeos are twin brothers who look exactly the same, from São Paulo. They paint many things, from small graffiti tags (short words or pictures on walls) to very large, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their paintings are often so big that they need cranes (tall machines that lift heavy objects) to help them. In 2007, they painted the whole outside of a castle in Scotland.
original: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.

simplified: People have painted and written on walls for a very long time. In prehistoric times (the time before written history), people in Africa and Europe drew pictures of animals and people on cave walls. Graffiti (drawings or words made on walls) has also been found on old buildings in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman city of Pompeii, scientists who study old things (archaeologists) discovered many pieces of graffiti written in Latin (the language spoken by the Romans). The graffiti includes messages about religion, politics, love, and even some magic spells.
original: People have been painting and writing on walls throughout history. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!

simplified: Have you ever dreamed of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If you have, you are not the only one. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world’s highest mountains or walk across big lands. In the past, explorers used maps and compasses (tools that show direction). Today, adventurers travel with modern technology such as GPS (a system that tells you where you are) and satellite phones (phones that work anywhere). Many adventurers love nature and use their trips to tell people about environmental problems (issues that affect the earth). Others want to help people in need and raise money for charities (organizations that help others).
original: Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's adventurers travel with modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. Many adventurers are nature lovers who use their travels to help raise awareness about a range of environmental issues, while others are keen to help people in need and raise money for charities.

simplified: The first mission is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test (a space mission that tries to change an asteroid’s path). The plan is to let DART hit the small moon of an asteroid named Didymos. This moon, called Didymoon, is about 150 metres wide and circles its larger partner, which is about 800 metres across. Scientists hope that the impact will move Didymoon enough for Earth‑based telescopes to notice.
original: The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are scheduled to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. 'Didymoon' is 150 metres wide, orbiting its 800-metre mother, and hopefully the impact of DART will knock it out of its orbit enough for Earth-based telescopes to pick up.

simplified: The main character is a sixteen‑year‑old girl named Katniss Everdeen. Her father died in a mining accident, so she has to get food for her family. She hunts in the forest near District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very good with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister Prim is chosen as a tribute (a person forced to take part in a deadly competition), Katniss volunteers to go instead. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta, and Katniss soon finds herself in a difficult relationship with him.
original: The heroine of the story, a sixteen year old girl called Katniss Everdeen, has lost her father in a mining accident and has to provide food for her family. She hunts in the woods around District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very skilful with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the tributes, Katniss volunteers to go instead. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta and Katniss soon finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.

simplified: When you write about your dreams, you will start to remember more details. Think about the people and places in the dream because they can help you understand its meaning. After a week you will be surprised at how much you have written. Then you can begin to connect your dreams with the events and feelings in your daily life.
original: Writing about your dreams will mean you start to remember more details about the dream, so think about the people and place where the dream happened as they might add to the meaning too. Over the period of a week you'll be surprised how much you've written down. Now you can start connecting your dreams to the events and feelings in your daily life.

simplified: In the past, many bridges were built from wood, so they could catch fire easily. This was especially true for old train bridges, where the steel wheels and tracks could make sparks that sometimes caused the wooden bridge to burn down.
original: Historically, more bridges were made of wood and were much more susceptible to fire. This was particularly true of old-fashioned train bridges, where the spark created by the steel wheels and steel tracks could sometimes cause a bridge to catch fire and burn to the ground.

simplified: It’s hard to know how street art will change in the future, but we can see some clear trends. Most street artists are still young people who paint in their own city or neighbourhood. However, more and more artists are travelling and creating art in different countries. Some artists also use the internet to talk to each other and share pictures of their work. The art world is starting to recognise street art as a real, important art form. Even though we can’t predict exactly what will happen, we know that street art is here to stay.
original: It is impossible to know how street art will develop in the future but certain trends are emerging. While most street artists are young people who paint in their city or neighbourhood, more and more street artists are travelling and working around the globe. Other artists are using the internet to talk to each other and share photos of their work. Also, the art world is giving more recognition to street art as a legitimate art form. Although we don't know what will happen to street art in the future, we can be sure that it is here to stay!

simplified: Suzanne Collines always finds war news on TV upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her by not telling her about the war, but Suzanne still saw news about it and knew her dad was there. It was a very scary experience for her.
original: Suzanne Collines has always found news programmes of wars upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and he fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her by not telling her what was happening in the war, but she still saw news programmes about the war and knew that her dad was there. It was a very frightening experience for her.

simplified: A worldwide survey by PwC received answers from more than 40,000 people, including millennials (born 1983‑1993) and others. They answered questions about work culture, communication, working styles, pay, career development, work‑life balance, and similar topics. A separate worldwide survey by Deloitte included over 10,000 millennials and asked them about the risks and opportunities they see in today’s complex work world.
original: In a global survey conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), more than 40,000 millennial (born between 1983 and 1993) and non-millennial responses were collected on the topics of workplace culture, communication and working styles, pay structure, career development, work–life balance, etc. In a separate global survey conducted by Deloitte, more than 10,000 millennials participated in a study about their perceptions of the threats and opportunities in the complex world of work.

simplified: Erik Weihenmayer is from the United States. He loves many kinds of adventure. He has ridden a bike in the deserts of Morocco, paddled a kayak in the Grand Canyon, and climbed Mount Everest (the highest mountain in the world). He has been blind since he was 13 years old. Besides his trips, he helps people with disabilities to stay active. He also leads groups of young blind people on climbing trips.
original: Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a multi-adventurer. He's ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked through the Grand Canyon and climbed Everest. Amazingly, Erik has been blind since the age of 13. Apart from his travels, he tries to encourage people with disabilities to live active lives and takes groups of young blind people on climbing expeditions.

simplified: Online platforms that anyone can use are giving people a chance to make a quick buck (extra money). For example, busy parents who used to avoid setting up a stall at the local market or a car‑boot sale can now sell their children’s almost‑new baby clothes, expensive pushchairs and other baby equipment on online marketplaces (websites where people buy and sell things). This lets them put some cash back into their pockets.
original: Democratised online platforms are providing a chance for people to make a quick buck or two. To give an example, busy parents previously might not have bothered with setting up a stall at the local market or car boot sale to sell their children's old equipment, but with online marketplaces, parents are now able to sell on those hardly worn baby clothes that their children have outgrown and the expensive pushchairs and baby equipment they have invested in, so as to put some cash back into their pockets.

simplified: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days together in a lifeboat. They have to deal with hunger, sickness and being very tired. They face strong storms and the hot Pacific sun, but they keep living. Sometimes Pi feels comfort from his three religions, and sometimes he feels very lonely and sad. At last, they see the Mexican coast on the horizon and everything changes. I won’t tell you the ending – you’ll have to read the book to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when land appears.
original: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the lifeboat. They live through hunger, illness and exhaustion. They endure violent storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun, but somehow they survive. At times, Pi finds comfort in his three religions, but at other times he is overcome with loneliness and despair. Finally, the Mexican coast appears on the horizon and everything changes. It would be a shame to give away the ending, so you will have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker once land is in sight.

simplified: Chloe got home from school, made a cup of coffee and took it to her bedroom. She had some homework, but she could do it later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet hour before her parents got home, when the house would fill with evening sounds – talking, the TV, or her dad listening to his favourite jazz while he cooked dinner. She liked this time because she could play with her pet rats.
original: Chloe arrived home from school, made herself a cup of coffee and took it up to her bedroom. She had some homework to do, but that could wait for later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet hour before her parents arrived home and the house filled up with the evening sounds of chatter, television or her dad listening to his beloved jazz while he cooked dinner. She liked this time of day too because she could play with her pet rats.

simplified: In 2010, NASA’s team that protects the planet found and recorded 90 % of the big asteroids that are about 1 km wide and come close to Earth. These asteroids are called “near‑Earth objects” (NEOs) – rocks that travel within about 50 million kilometres of Earth’s orbit. Scientists think there are still about 50 more to find. NASA says that none of the 887 NEOs we already know about are a serious danger to Earth.
original: In 2010, the planetary defence team at NASA had identified and logged 90 per cent of the asteroids near Earth measuring 1km wide. These 'near-Earth objects', or NEOs, are the size of mountains and include anything within 50 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. With an estimated 50 left to log, NASA says none of the 887 it knows about are a significant danger to the planet.

simplified:
Auggie finally decides to go to school, and now he has to face his first day. Like every child who starts at a new school, he feels very nervous. Because of the way he looks, the first day is especially painful. No one wants to sit next to him, and he sees other kids staring at him or talking about him behind their hands. Luckily, he becomes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he talks to at lunch.

The first day is not the only hard part. Auggie soon finds out that his classmates do not want to touch him because they are scared of catching “the plague” – a serious disease that they think he might have. Throughout the school year Auggie experiences many strong ups and downs. Then, an unexpected and very upsetting event at a school camp changes everything.
original: Having decided to go to school, Auggie then has to face his first day. Like every child starting at a new school, he is really anxious. But because of the way he looks, it's an agonising experience. Nobody wants to sit next to him and he notices other kids staring at him or talking about him behind their hands. Fortunately, he makes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he chats with at lunch. But it's not just the first day that's hard. Auggie soon learns that his classmates don't want to touch him for fear of catching 'the plague'. As he goes through the school year, Auggie goes through many intense ups and downs till finally an unexpected and traumatic event at a school camp changes things completely.

simplified: The two men turned to look at the north side of the land. It went on as far as they could see. The fences were almost invisible from where they stood. Even if a teenage boy felt bored and wanted to rebel, he could not run away on foot. Sam looked at the biggest horse, kicking the ground with its heavy hooves (the hard feet of a horse). Could the boy ride it? he wondered. A good rider could get into a lot of trouble out here, far away from anyone. But someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father could get even more trouble.
original: The two men looked towards the northern end of the property. It stretched as far as the eye could see. Even the fences were barely visible from where they stood. However bored and rebellious a teenage boy might get, it wasn't possible to escape on foot. Sam looked at the biggest of the horses, kicking at the ground with its heavy hooves. Could the boy ride? he wondered. There was a whole load of trouble a good rider could get into out here, miles away from anyone. But maybe there was even more trouble for someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father.

simplified: More than 4,000 climbers, from 13 to 80 years old, have reached the top of Everest. Climbing high mountains in cold weather and strong storms is still very dangerous, but the best climbers in the world now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria fell in love with mountain climbing when she was a teenager. After she left school, she worked as a nurse, but she kept climbing in her free time.
original: Over 4,000 climbers, aged from thirteen to eighty have been to the top of Everest. Though climbing high mountains in freezing conditions and violent storms is still extremely dangerous, the world's best climbers now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria fell in love with mountain climbing as a teenager. When she left school, she worked as a nurse, but kept climbing in her free time.

simplified: After she climbed Mount Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all 14 mountains in the world that are 8,000 metres high. She climbs them without using oxygen tanks (equipment that gives extra air), which makes the climbs harder. This is risky because there is little oxygen at the top of very high mountains, and the lack of oxygen can affect how the brain and body work. Gerlinde uses her fame as a climber to support a charity that helps poor children and orphans in Nepal.
original: Having climbed Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's 8,000 metre peaks. To increase the challenge, Gerlinde climbs without using oxygen tanks. This is risky as low oxygen levels at the top of high mountains can affect brain and body functioning. Gerlinde uses her fame as a climber to support a charity for poor children and orphans in Nepal.

simplified: When we think about the things we have bought, we can see that many of them are not used much. For example, a thick wool coat that looks fashionable even though we live in a hot, tropical country. A smartphone that stays in a drawer after we buy a newer model. A car that is only driven on weekends. Or a guest room in our house that has become a storage room.
original: If we look around us at the things we have purchased at some point in our lives, we would no doubt notice that not everything we own is being put to good use: the thick woollen coat which we thought looked trendy despite the fact that we live in a tropical country, the smartphone that got put away when we bought ourselves the newest model, the car that only gets used at the weekends, or even the guest room in our house that somehow got turned into a storeroom.

simplified: For a long time and in many cultures, people have linked dreams with predicting the future. They believed dreams were messages from the gods, sent to give us knowledge (information) or insight (understanding). Even today, many people remember a time when they dreamed about an event, a place, or a person, and later that dream came true in real life.
original: Throughout history and across cultures, dreams have been associated with prophecy. People thought dreams were messages from the gods, sent to give us knowledge or insight. Even today, many people can recall a time they dreamed about an event, place or person and then, later, the dream came true in real life.

simplified: Some of the biggest and most costly transport projects in the world have been about building bridges. Bridges are important connections that let cars, trucks and trains go over water, deep valleys or other roads. Because of this, they are a key part of civil engineering (the work of designing and building public structures) and they are watched very closely, especially when they collapse.
original: Some of the biggest and most expensive transportation projects in the world have involved building bridges. Bridges are crucial links that carry cars, trucks and trains across bodies of water, mountain gorges or other roads. As a result, they are one of the most important aspects of civil engineering and are subject to intense scrutiny, especially when they collapse.

simplified: After weeks of feeling frustrated, Gabriela wrote an email to her Swedish boss about the problems she had with her team. Her boss only asked if she thought her team was still doing a good job and what could help her work better with the team members. Gabriela thought her boss was unclear and did not think he handled the problem well.
original: After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her Swedish manager about the issues she was facing with her team. Her manager simply asked her if she felt her team was still performing, and what she thought would help her better collaborate with her team members. Gabriela found her manager vague and didn't feel as if he was managing the situation satisfactorily.

simplified: Dogs that live in groups have learned that people give food to small, cute dogs. So those dogs go to ask for food for the whole group. Some dogs even learned to use the city’s metro to move around their area. Scientists do not know how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their strong sense of smell and recognize the smells of the places they like. Another idea is that they have learned the names of the stations from the announcements. Either way, metro passengers have become used to seeing dogs on the trains, so the dogs travel almost unnoticed by locals.
original: Dogs that live in packs have learnt that humans are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs so those dogs are sent to beg for food for the whole pack. Some dogs have even learnt to use the city's metro system to get from one part of their territory to another! Scientists are not sure how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their excellent sense of smell and have learnt to recognise the scents of their favourite destinations. Another possibility is that they have learnt to recognise the names of stations they hear in announcements. Either way, metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals.

simplified: Ed Stafford, a man from the UK, was the first person to walk the whole length of the Amazon River. He began at a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru and finished at the river’s mouth (the place where the river meets the sea) in Brazil. The journey took two years and four months, and he walked about 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest has dangerous animals such as poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars, so Ed was always in danger. Fortunately, he only got many mosquito and ant bites and no serious injuries.
original: Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. He started by a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru and arrived at the river's mouth in Brazil, two years and four months later, having walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest is home to poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars, so Ed was in constant danger. Luckily, he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.

simplified:
In Britain, most people spend more than £1,000 on new clothes each year. That is about four percent of what they earn. It does not look like a lot, but it hides two serious problems for people and for the environment.

First, a lot of this money is paid with credit cards. On average, each adult in Britain owes about £670 to credit‑card companies. That means two‑thirds of the money they spend on clothes is actually borrowed, not earned.

Second, people are using this borrowed money to buy things they do not really need. Because of this, Britain throws away about 300,000 tonnes of clothing every year. Most of this waste ends up in landfill sites – places where rubbish is buried.
original: In Britain, the average person spends more than £1,000 on new clothes a year, which is around four per cent of their income. That might not sound like much, but that figure hides two far more worrying trends for society and for the environment. First, a lot of that consumer spending is via credit cards. British people currently owe approximately £670 per adult to credit card companies. That's 66 per cent of the average wardrobe budget. Also, not only are people spending money they don't have, they're using it to buy things they don't need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothing a year, most of which goes into landfill sites.

simplified: Ed could not have made the walk without technology. He used a radio to ask the rainforest people for food and to get permission to go through their land. Many of them came to meet him and showed him the hardest parts of the land. While he walked, Ed wrote a blog about his daily experiences. He used the news attention on his trip to speak out against the cutting down of the rainforest and to collect money for charities (organizations that raise money for good causes) that help the environment and children in Brazil and Peru.
original: Ed's walk would have been impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people of the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land. Many of them came to meet him and helped guide him through the most difficult terrain. As he walked Ed wrote a blog, recording his day-to-day experiences. He used the media interest in his trip to protest about the destruction of the rainforest and raise money for environmental and children's charities in Brazil and Peru.

simplified: Businesses have realized that the sharing economy can be profitable and they want to use unused resources. A popular business model is companies that run an online platform connecting customers with people who can offer a product or service. Companies like Airbnb act as a middleman, helping people rent out their empty rooms or houses for extra money. Another example is Uber, which lets people use their own cars as taxis to earn some extra cash in their free time.
original: Businesses have caught on to the profitability of the sharing economy and are seeking to gain from making use of those underutilised resources. A business model that has rapidly risen in popularity sees companies providing an online platform that puts customers in contact with those who can provide a particular product or service. Companies like Airbnb act as a middleman for people to cash in on their unused rooms and houses and let them out as lucrative accommodation. Another example is Uber, which encourages people to use their own personal cars as taxis to make some extra cash in their free time.

simplified: One of the main jobs of modern zoos is to help international breeding programmes, especially for endangered animals. In the wild, some rare species find it hard to find mates and have babies, and they can also be threatened by poachers, loss of their habitat, and predators. A good zoo lets these animals live and breed in a safe environment. Also, when the numbers of some wild species go down, there is a higher risk that the populations become too genetically similar. Breeding programmes give protection: animals born in zoos can be released into the wild to increase genetic diversity.
original: One of the most important modern functions of zoos is supporting international breeding programmes, particularly for endangered species. In the wild, some of the rarest species have difficulty in finding mates and breeding, and they might also be threatened by poachers, loss of their habitat and predators. A good zoo will enable these species to live and breed in a secure environment. In addition, as numbers of some wild species drop, there is an increased danger of populations becoming too genetically similar. Breeding programmes provide a safeguard: zoo-bred animals can be released into the wild to increase genetic diversity.

simplified: Both kinds of accidents are very rare, but boats and trains can make a bridge fall down for different reasons. With trains, it is the speed of the impact (speed = how fast something is moving) that can bring a bridge down. With boats, it is their very large weight (mass = how much material something has) that can cause the collapse, even if they are moving slowly. The best way to avoid bridge failures is to plan for them. Modern technology that can detect weak parts in a bridge, safer work environments and better designs can all help to reduce these terrible accidents.
original: Both of these kinds of accidents are extremely rare, but boats and trains can cause a bridge to collapse for different reasons. With trains, it's the velocity of the impact that can bring a bridge down. With boats, it's the very large mass they have that can bring about the collapse, even if they are moving very slowly when it occurs. The best way to avoid bridge failures is to plan for them. Modern technologies that can detect structural weakness, safer working environments and better designs can all help to reduce these terrible accidents.

simplified: At first, Pi is very scared of the animals and jumps into the sea. Then he thinks about the hungry sharks swimming nearby and sees that his only choice is to get back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, until only Pi and the tiger are left. Luckily for Pi, the tiger, which he calls Richard Parker, feels seasick and does not want to eat him right away.
original: At first, Pi is terrified of the animals and jumps into the ocean. Then he remembers that there are hungry sharks in the water around him and realises his only option is to climb back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, till only Pi and the tiger are left. Fortunately for Pi, the tiger, who he names Richard Parker, is seasick and has no immediate interest in eating him.

simplified: When Pi is 16, a new government is chosen that his parents do not like. Worried about what will happen, his parents close the zoo and decide to **move** (go to live in another country) to Canada. They sell some animals to zoos in North America and travel by ship to Canada, taking the animals with them. During the trip a huge storm hits and the ship sinks. Sadly, Pi’s family and the sailors die in the water, but Pi ends up in a small lifeboat with a hyena, a zebra, an **orang‑utan** (a large ape from the jungle) and a very big tiger.
original: When Pi is 16, a new government is elected that his parents don't support. Worried about the future, Pi's parents decide to close the zoo and emigrate to Canada. Some of the animals are sold to zoos in North America and the family travel by ship to Canada taking the animals with them. On the way, there is a terrible storm and the ship sinks. Tragically, Pi's family and the ship's sailors all drown, but Pi finds himself in a lifeboat with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan and an enormous tiger.

simplified: The Hunger Games is a very popular book for teens and young adults. It was written by the American author Suzanne Collins and first published in 2008. Since then it has been translated into 26 languages and has sold millions of copies worldwide. It was also the first book for young readers to sell more than one million digital copies (electronic versions you can read on a computer or tablet). The story was later made into a big Hollywood movie, and the film is also a huge success. In its first weekend in North America the movie earned 152.5 million dollars.
original: The Hunger Games is a hugely successful book for teenagers and young adults by the American author Suzanne Collins. Since it was published in 2008 it has been translated into 26 different languages and has sold millions of copies around the world. It is also the first book for young readers to sell more than a million electronic copies. The Hunger Games is now a major Hollywood film and is just as successful. It made 152.5 million dollars in its opening weekend in North America alone!

simplified: Maybe dreams happen because our mind sorts the thoughts we had during the day, but they show up in dreams as symbols (pictures that stand for ideas). When we are awake, we think mainly in words, like we talk to ourselves. When we sleep, the part of the brain that controls language works less, and the part that controls emotions works more.
original: Maybe dreams are the result of our mind organising the thoughts we have during the day, but they appear in dreams with symbolic meaning. When we're awake, our thoughts mostly appear in our minds as words, like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active while the part that controls emotions becomes more active.

simplified: Having good relationships helps us feel happy. A study showed that most happy people have strong connections with friends and family and they make time to be with them often. They also have at least one person they can share personal feelings with – this is called self‑disclosure (talking openly about your inner thoughts). One close person, together with a wider circle of other friends, is enough. It is not enough to have many friends only for activities or to talk about music or football. A deeper, more personal connection is very important. Some people need to learn how to listen carefully to others to make their relationships stronger.
original: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were found to have strong ties to friends and family and they made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – called 'self-disclosure'. Just one person for a heart-to-heart is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.

simplified: Psychologist Carol Dweck, who studies the “growth mindset,” says that the brain can change (it is “plastic”) and that we can learn new skills even if we were not good at them before. Many people usually praise the final result and what seems to be natural talent, for example: “You have a good eye for details” or “You are really good at planning events.” But research shows that if we praise the way a person works – the effort they put in, trying new ideas, and the ways they solve problems – we help them build new abilities and keep improving their talents.
original: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.

simplified: The rover looks at the air around it from time to time. In 2014 it found that the air had another simple organic molecule and a main part of natural gas: methane. Methane does not last very long – only a few hundred years. This tells us that something on Mars is making more of it again. NASA says Mars lets out thousands of tonnes of methane at once. The amount of methane goes up and down with the seasons, almost like the planet is breathing.
original: The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is replenishing the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.

simplified:
Early in her career, psychologist Carol Dweck from Stanford University gave a group of ten‑year‑old children problems that were a little too hard for them.  

One group answered positively. They said they liked the challenge and believed they could get better with practice. This is called a **growth mindset** – the idea that you can improve your abilities over time.  

The other group felt that their intelligence was being judged and that they had failed. They had a **fixed mindset** – the belief that your abilities cannot change. These children could not picture getting better. Some said they might cheat in the future; others tried to find someone who did worse than them so they would feel better about themselves.
original: Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.

simplified: Horror movies like places where nobody lives. This can be an old hospital, a scary empty house, or a ghost town (a town with no people). There is something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it is also because they are very quiet, which can be scary too. Abandoned places (places that have been left empty) are useful for horror movie directors because it feels more real that there is no phone signal there.
original: Horror films love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so quiet, which can be very scary too. Of course, abandoned places are also handy for horror film directors in that it's more believable that you will have no phone coverage there either.

simplified: No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror movies. It is often where something hides or where a dangerous person (a psychopath) keeps their tools. Basements are usually dark and often damp (wet). You can only get to them by a narrow staircase. And basements always feel creepy, even when there is nothing down there.
original: No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the evil psychopath has hidden their tools. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always creepy, even when there isn't anything down there.

simplified: Gary Collins, a police officer who was off duty, was watching the London riots on TV. He instantly recognized several people and ended his holiday early to help identify them. He spent six months looking at CCTV (security‑camera) footage and was able to name 190 people, many just by looking at their eyes. His help was very important for the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of video, facial‑recognition software (a computer program that matches faces) could only find one person.
original: Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with identification. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and managed to identify 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was of decisive importance in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, facial recognition software managed to identify just one person.

simplified: Personally, I find it amazing to think about how we can make our evolution faster by adding new parts to our bodies. Imagine putting a computer inside our brain! Soon we will be able to do that and improve our math skills, our ability to see and hear, and our memory. This idea will become more and more common.
original: Personally, I think it's fascinating to consider how we'll speed up our evolution as a species by augmenting our bodies. Imagine if you could implant a computer inside our brain! Soon we'll be able to do just that and enhance our mathematical ability, audiovisual perception and our memory, and this idea is only going to become more and more commonplace.

simplified: It was an interesting talk and the speaker said exactly the right things about a few topics. For example, think about how parents affect their children. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing homework if they see their parents posting on social media while cooking dinner or waiting at a red light? She also pointed out that many people want to be in two or more places at the same time. So they keep moving between real‑life talks and online chats. I see this often with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet, sit together in silence, and each one talks on their phone or computer with different people online.
original: It was a fascinating talk and the speaker really hit the nail on the head with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing their homework when they witness their parents posting on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light? She also made a valid point about people wanting to be in two or several places at once. So they switch back and forth between their real-life and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet and then sit together in silence while each one engages in a different conversation online.

simplified:
News often makes us feel that the world is becoming more violent, but there are also reasons to be hopeful.  

From the end of World War II (the big war that finished in 1945) until 1990, there were 30 wars in which more than 100,000 people died.  

Today we still have civil wars (fights inside a country), but most countries live together more peacefully than before.  

In the last few years, terrorism (violent attacks by groups that want political change) has increased a lot.  

Since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians (people who are not soldiers) than soldiers.  

Even for civilians, the numbers are not all bad.  

A person is about nine times more likely to die from violent crime (like murder) than from political conflict (war).  

The worldwide murder rate has gone down a little: it was 8 deaths for every 100,000 people in the year 2000 and about 5.3 deaths per 100,000 people in 2015.
